list_definition.definition: (in football/soccer, hockey etc) in a position (not allowed by the rules) between the ball and the opponents’ goal

list_ex_of_definition.ex_of_definition: The referee disallowed the goal because one of the players had moved offside
also adjective He was in an offside position.

list_definition.definition: (of a vehicle etc) on the side nearest to the centre/center of the road

list_ex_of_english: Existing signs direct drivers into the offside lanes if they wish to remain on the motorway, and into the nearside lane if they wish to leave it.
There were a total of six offsides calls, split evenly between the two teams.
As he fairly pointed out, it is not always possible to generalise on whether it is right to turn from the offside or the nearside.
We are trying to keep the goalposts where they were, but in this case the interpretation of the offside rule has been a complication.
Is it not possible to devise some form of guard which would prevent that wave going out on the offside?
Offsides is penalized by a 30-second penalty.
There is no other penalties in the game, making offsides and roughing the quarterback into workable strategies.
The match had a total of 22 fouls and 6 offsides, both statistics split evenly between the two teams.
